Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Global RF Spectrum Opportunity Assessment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
In order to apply emerging technologies (e.g. dynamic spectrum sharing) to address the wireless spectrum shortage problem, there is a critical need to understand global RF spectrum usage trends. To accomplish this, a three-pronged approach is being pursued: 1) deployment of geographically dispersed, temporally coordinated RF spectrum observatories in multiple U.S. locations, and through international collaboration, in Finland. The spectrum observatories use a common platform generating a single RF spectrum measurement dataset. 2) Development of empirically validated, statistical models of spectrum utilization for different wireless application types based on this dataset. 3) Use of "big data" analytical techniques to mine the dataset to discover temporal and spectral correlations not obvious using traditional approaches. As the models and relationships are refined, they will enable temporal and spectral occupancy predictions to support spectrum sharing for various circumstances and wireless applications.

The generation of a high-resolution, multi-location, multi-national spectrum usage dataset using a common, consistent measurement and storage approach is unique and allows direct, unambiguous comparisons of spectrum usage across geographies and demographics. The statistical models of spectrum utilization and the identified similarities and differences between regions and wireless services are unique and inform dynamic spectrum sharing research and related regulatory action with "real-world" data. Importantly, this is the first time that "big data" analytic approaches are being systematically applied to RF utilization data providing new insights motivating novel dynamic spectrum sharing approaches and improved spectrum efficiency.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Global RF Spectrum Opportunity Assessment project enabled researchers from five organization (two U.S. - Virginia Tech and Illinois Institute of Technology and two Finnish Universities - University of Oulu and Turku University of Applied Science and a Finnish Research Institute - VTT) to collaboratively build the infrastructure to make and store global spectrum measurements and perform associated analyses and visualization work on their measurements. In this process data was gathered in Turku, Finland; London, England; Blacksburg, VA; and Chicago, IL. This data was in turn analyzed using various well-established and in some cases relatively new techniques. As a component of this analysis work, comparisons were made between the spectrum data and information about the environment in which the spectrum data was taken. 

Perhaps the most noteworthy achievement from the physical infrastructure perspective was the implementation of five nearly identical spectrum observation stations. One of these is located in Blacksburg, VA, and enables the comparison of spectrum utilization between this small town in a relatively rural area and the other observation stations located in more heavily populated areas. These stations provided the spectrum measurements that were the basis for the various spectrum comparisons made between the sites. The data was collected and ultimately stored in a large data storage facility located at Illinois Institute of Technology. 

This project at Virgnia Tech succeeded in developing new mathematical tools for understanding the impact of large-scale human events on spectrum occupancy, and for the development of better mathematical models of spectrum occupancy more generally. In particular, the project developed new models for spectrum occupancy based on Hidden Markov Models (HMMs). These models enable the prediction of the behavior of so-called "primary users" of radio spectrum, which enables other users to use the spectrum more efficiently. We also studied the impact of large-scale events such as Virginia Tech football games, Chicago White Sox baseball games, and outdoor concerts and track-and-field events in Finland on the use of spectrum. These studies will enable future policy makers to better prepare for the specturm needs associated with different types of events, as well as to use spectrum measurements to recognize changes in spectrum usage in real-time. 

Beyond the technical achievements of the group, the opportunity to share weekly Skype interactions supplemented by conference meetings and yearly in-person WiFiUS interactions at the Faculty and student level across the five organization was a positive aspect of the program. These interactions promoted cultural exchanges of various forms between the groups. Gaining an enhanced understanding of the related spectrum policy dynamics in the U.S. and Europe and comparing those with the efforts at the ITU-R was of particular interest to the research program.

Overall, this program was a significant success from the scientific, infrastructure development, and the personal develop and enhanced cultural understanding perspectives.  It is hoped that this program will be continued and that others will have similar opportunities in the future.
